content.question: A scientist is studying the relationship of two quantities <math alttext="S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in an experiment. The scientist finds that under certain conditions, as the quantity of <math alttext="S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> increases, the quantity of <math alttext="T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> decreases. After taking measurements, the scientist determines that the rate of change of the quantity of <math alttext="S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> with respect to the quantity of <math alttext="T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> present is inversely proportional to the natural logarithm of the quantity of <math alttext="T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following is a differential equation that could describe this relationship?

choices.label: <math alttext="S equals, the fraction with numerator k, and denominator the natural log of T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>S</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>, where <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></math> is a nonzero constant.

<math alttext="the derivative of S, with respect to T, equals, the fraction with numerator the natural log of t, and denominator k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>, where <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></math> is a nonzero constant.

<math alttext="the derivative of S, with respect to T, equals, the fraction with numerator k, and denominator the natural log of T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>, where <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></math> is a nonzero constant.

<math alttext="the derivative of T, with respect to S, equals, the fraction with numerator k, and denominator the natural log of S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>S</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>S</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>, where <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></math> is a nonzero constant.

content.answer: <math alttext="the derivative of S, with respect to T, equals, the fraction with numerator k, and denominator the natural log of T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>, where <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></math> is a nonzero constant.

skill.text: Skill 2.C: Identify a re-expression of mathematical information presented in a given representation
